publicationStmt.p: This is an XML-TEI markup of the original publications by SIL Mexico for the purposes of: archival and for the creation of a body of Mixtepec-Mixtec language resources (LR) (ISO: mix). Encoded documents used with the permission of original authors.

notesStmt.note: Este cuento relata cómo a un niño se le quitaron las ganas de matar pájaros.

sourceDesc.bibl: María Gómez Hernández Gisela Beckmann María M. Nieves Ña niyu'u nchu'a Instituto Lingüístico de Verano, A.C. Tlalpan, D.F., México second 2008 Obtained from:

normalization.ab: 2018-02-18Spelling of lexical items which in the old orthography were homographs and which have been changed according to updated orthographic principles as per ../Mille/GUIA_ORTOGRAFICA_PRELIMINAR_Short_version.xml. Instances of "ña" still remain to be changed pending consultation with Mille (or other person working on orthography). In this document the extended senses of "face" - "nuu" were not normalized as I am awaiting discussion as to whether this particular sense should also be changed to "nu". "tutu" 'wood' changed to "tutú"

list.item: Mixtec content found at following locations: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg/w

English translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalentwhere preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

Spanish translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalentwhere preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

spanGrp.span: One upon a time liver was a little boy.
Érase una vez vivía un niño.
He always wanted to kill birds.
Also a multi-word expression "ta'an ta ini"
Whenever he would see a bird, he would always follow it.
Cuando veía un pájaro, so siempre siguería.
Then one day he saw a little bird with very pretty feathers, he looked for his slingshot and started to shoot it.
Y un día vió un pájaro pequeño con plumas muy bonitas, buscó su resortera y empezó a tirarle.
"ti" functioning as the semantic role of undergoer (or object)
Then the little bird flew away. It was sitting on a tree branch and the little boy came back and again shot at it again as he approached the little bird.
Y el pájaro pequeño pájaro salió volando. Se sentaba en una rama de árbol y el niño pequeño volvió y le tiró de nuevo cuando acercaba el pájaro pequeño.
"ntsi-" is the imperfective prefix (or at least what functions as such as I'm not sure what the SIL people refer to it as.)
And then, just like that the bird flew away up to a tree. And once again, the little boy once again followed it.
Y de repente, el pájaro salió volando hasta un árbol y de nuevo, el niño lo seguió.
Can this mean "(in) the same way", "likewise"?
And then it was getting dark and the little bird flew and went away.
Y entonces oscurecía y el pájaro pequeño voló y se fue.
Then the little boy fell and sat down crying because it was night time.
Y entonces el niño pequeño se cayó llorando porque estaba la noche.
is this a verb? Does this mean "be dark" or "night"? How do you say: "night"? "dark"?
Then when it was morning the next day a little boy was sitting down crying.
Luego la mañana del día siguente un niño se sentaba llorando.
what POS is this? is this the noun for "daytime"? what is the set of: "day" - "night"? How to you say: "it is daytime" - "it is night time"?
also means 'tomorrow', add to existing entry in Dictionary
Then a man looking for wood heard the crying and came up to and saw where the boy was sitting down.
Y un hombre buscando madera oyó los gritos y vinó y vió dónde el niño se estaba sentado.
(check with speakers!) this appears to be a nominalizer "ña". Check why the verb would be inflected with "-a" though..
(ask speaker) so is this parsable literally as: "what are you making that you are crying?"
Estoy llorando por qué tengo miedo.
also a phrase/MWE "yu'u ta yu" V ADV 1S
Don't cry, I'm chopping wood now. Let's go home, I'll go and I can drop you off at your house.....
No lloras, orita estoy cortando madera. Vamos a casa y yo iré y te dejo a tu casa.....
so does the placement of "kaka" and a potential object make the phrase into "wander after (X)"?
Then the very scared little boy never returned to kill birds ever again.
Y el niño pequeño muy asustado nunca jamás volvió para matar pájaros.
the lemma of this is "yu'u xeen" and inflecting it for 3pers makes the vowel change in the adverbial portion of the MWE to "xiin".
